thread.title: Getting the kids hooked on fly fishing with a guide in the Vail Valley
thread.title_full: Getting the kids hooked on fly fishing with a guide in the Vail Valley - The Denver Post

author: Chryss Cada
title: Getting the kids hooked on fly fishing with a guide in the Vail Valley
text:
EDWARDS —Everybody is a little kid when they have a big fish on the line.
During a recent family fishing trip in the Vail Valley, the "I got one" expression looked exactly the same on my 74-year-old dad as it did on my 8- and 10-year-old daughters.
I guess that's because the fun of catching a fish never gets old.
When Mike and Bill from Fly Fishing Outfitters took us up to some private ponds near Cordillera in early July, it had been more than three decades since my last fishing trip.
When I was young I went fishing with my Dad and brother on a regular basis. And while I don't remember a single fish any of us caught, I do recall the peace of those high mountain lakes.
When my brother died at age 15, we scattered his ashes at one of our favorite fishing spots, American Lakes near Gould. I haven't been fishing since.
My dad, who first picked up a pole as a 7-year-old growing up in Montana's Flathead Valley, still communes with the fish at least once a week March to December. He took my daughters a few times when they were barely old enough to hold a pole, but they never saw the appeal of waiting around for the opportunity to watch something slimy flop around on the rocks within touching distance of their feet.
But fishermen don't give up easily, so Dad and I brought along two guides on the Vail trip to make the fishing conditions for the girls as ideal as humanly possible.
Advertisement "Ideal" is actually the first word that came to mind as we pulled into Red Draw Ranch. The trout-stocked ponds, creeks and waterfalls were surrounded by so many daisies there was more white than green. Pine-filled hillsides hid the nearby highway, giving way only to the taller peaks behind. The setting was so perfect I felt like I was revisiting a memory instead of making one.
Not slowed by the scenery, the rest of the crew made a mad dash to the closest pond.
I reached for my camera to try to capture the moment but was interrupted by my younger daughter holding her hands about 18 inches apart and shouting, "Mama! Mama! I can see a fish, and it's THIS BIG!!" Wow, these guides work fast. We hadn't even been on the water 30 seconds and she had already had the first lesson in fishing: how to lie about the size of fish.
Skeptically I walked over to the side of the pond and took a look. Sailing through the clear water was not only one fish that size, but three.
I've never seen my father move as quickly as when he reached for a fly rod. What happened next was almost as amazing as the size of those fish — he offered the rod to my daughters first.
All of a sudden everyone was as panicky as a 6-year-old trying to find money as the ice cream truck comes down the block. Here's where the beauty of having a guide comes in. Bill and Mike handed us rods loaded up with fishes' favorite flies, told us where to cast them and how to maneuver them once they got there.
My younger daughter was the first to get a bite. The monster struck with so much force that it broke her line. From then on, she held onto her pole with both hands, like it was the rope in a tug-of-war. After Bill tied on a new fly, she couldn't get back in the game fast enough.
I've never seen her so patient, a quality that I've often tried (and failed) to cultivate.
Every time she wanted to give up, another lunker would bend her pole down to the water. She was hooked.
Despite bites all around, my dad was the only one to land a fish that day. That said, I believe his granddaughter's interest in the sport was his real catch. The two of them were already planning their next fishing trip when it was time to leave the ponds.
Chryss Cada is a freelance writer and adjunct professor of journalism at Colorado State University. Visit her at www.chryss.com.
Flights and flies
Colorado's shoulder seasons are actually prime fishing time, because it's when the fish are hatching. The Antlers at Vail (antlersvail.com) has a new package that lets locals take advantage of this quieter time in the mountains. "Flights and Flies" includes two nights at the Antlers, a half-day fishing trip with Fly Fishing Outfitters and a whiskey tasting flight with 10th Mountain Whiskey & Spirit Co. (10thWhiskey.com), a Vail craft distillery and tasting room.
